document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Involving patients in primary care : lessons for primary care organisations
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,SERVICE DELIVERY,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This article reports the results of a national postal questionnaire to chief executives of primary care organisations (PCOs) in England and two in depth case studies of public involvement in decision making in primary care organisations. The case studies took place in the Trent region. The study is placed in the context of the development of public involvement in decision-making in the NHS. The national survey revealed a high level of commitment to public involvement, and significant efforts to involve the public were being made but there was little evidence of clear strategic policy. The case studies identified considerable activity related to public involvement in both PCOs, and again little evidence of written strategies or policy to direct the activity. Findings indicated that success in engaging the public was greater where attempts were made to work in partnership and build longer-term relationships. Despite this, PCOs were undertaking a substantial amount of public meetings and events to inform the public. There appeared to be a lack of a strategic approach to public involvement, which could undermine the evident enthusiasm of PCOs and the public.

 

This article was originally published in Research Policy and Planning (2004) vol. 22 no. 1.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Involving patients in primary care consultations : assessing preferences using discrete choice experiments
document.publisher: British Journal of General Practice : the journal of the Royal College of General Practitioners
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,SHARED DECISION MAKING,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Background

Shared decision making (SDM) involves patients and doctors contributing as partners to treatment decisions. It is not known whether or to what extent SDM contributes to the welfare arising from a consultation, and how important this contribution is relative to other attributes of a consultation.

 

Aim

To identify patient preferences for SDM relative to other utility bearing attributes of a consultation.

 

 

Design of study

In parallel with a randomised trial in training GPs in SDM competencies and risk communication skills, a discrete choice experiement exercise was conducted to assess patients' utilities.

 

Setting

Twenty general practices in South Wales, UK.

 

Method

Five hundred and eighty-four responders from 747 patients attending the randomised trial (response rate = 78%). All patients had one of four conditions (atrial fibrillation, menorrhagia, menopausal symptoms or prostatism) and attended a consultation either with a doctor who had received no training in the study or risk communication training alone or SDM training alone, or both combined.

 

Results

Five key utility bearing attributes of a consultation were identified. All significantly influenced patient's choice of preferred consultation style (P<0.001). Larger increases in utility were associated with changes on 'doctor listens' attribute, followed by easily understood information, a shared treatment decision, more information and longer consultation. Utilities were influenced by whether the doctor had received risk communication training alone or SDM training alone, or both combined, prior to the consultations. The randomised trial itself had identified that the communication processes of these consultations changed significantly, with greater patient involvement in decision making, after the training interventions.

 

Conclusion

Shared treatment decisions were valued less than some other attributes of a consultation. However, patient utilities for such involvement appeared responsive to changes in expereinces of consultations. This suggests that SDM may gain greater value among patients once they have experienced it.

 

This article was published in Br J Gen Pract. 2006 January 1; 56(522): 35–42.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Involving people : a practical guide
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES]]>
document.body:
This guide is for all front line staff and managers of public services who want to improve those services through talking to, and involving, the people who use them. It will help with the part of a project that is to do with choosing and implementing the method that is going to be used. It will help in choosing the most appropriate method for achieving aims and give step-by-step instructions for carrying it out.

Methods described include:

Active suggestion boxes
Cafe consultations
Focus groups
Fun days and festivals
Interviews
Involving people in recruitment
Mystery shoppers
Newsletters
Open space events
Posters and leaflets
Public meetings
Representatives on committees
Surveys and questionnaires
Talking to people
User forums
Using the creative arts
Video booths
Visioning workshops

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Involving people in public disclosure of clinical data : report on research with user organisations and patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,MONITORING AND QUALITY ASSURANCE]]>
document.body:
The Nuffield Trust has supported a programme, working with RAND Health, on achieving improvements in healthcare quality through the public release of information about performance. In the first phase of this programme, projects were carried out in the acute sector (on the public release of data on mortality in cardiac artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery) and in primary care (on data for clinical quality assessment in general practice).

 

Both these projects focused on the experience of health care professionals, and on developing and improving systems to support the publication of data on clinical performance which would be credible and useful to these professionals and at the same time contribute to the understanding of managers and policy makers.

 

This report, published in 2003, complements these two projects. It drew on the experience and support of RAND Health and the California Healthcare Foundation. As with the cardiac and primary care projects, this study of involving the public in the public release of information about performance demonstrates the importance for the United Kingdom of learning from experience on the other side of the Atlantic.

]]>

The key messages of the guide apply also to developing service users’ and carers’ involvement in all types of training for social work and social care staff and in the design and delivery of services.]]>

document.body:
This booklet aims to give researchers working within the NHS, social care and public health fields some guidelines on how best to involve the public in their work.  There are some examples of good practice in involving people who use services which may be of particular use to researchers new to, or just starting to involve the public. It is hoped that it will also be read by members of the public who are involved in research and development in health and social care so that they know about the good practice it is suggested researchers follow.

 

This document is also available to download in large print.

 

A complementary booklet for members of the public who are interested in getting involved in research called Getting Involved in Research: A Guide for Consumers has also been produced.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Involving users and carers in care management in mental health : research summary
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES,SHARED DECISION MAKING,CONSULTING PATIENTS AND PUBLIC,SERVICE DELIVERY,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,PEOPLE WITH MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This is a summary of a research report 'Choice, Information and Dignity: involving service users and carers in care management in mental health', published in 1997, which is now out of print. The purpose of this research study was to find out if mental health services can be more responsive to the needs of people with severe and long-term mental health problems. It also aimed to establish if it is possible to involve service users and their carers effectively in developing plans ('care programmes') for their care and treatment in the community.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Involving users in shaping motor neurone disease services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
BUILD (Building User InvoLvement in MND) was a one-year project exploring how people with MND and their families could be involved in planning and monitoring the delivery of the health and social care services they were using.

 

The project used community development strategies to develop user involvement and empower people affected by MND, and was based in an NHS specialist MND Care and Research Centre which had a positive approach to user involvement.

 

The main project activities were: qualitative research interviews with people with MND, their informal carers and relevant professionals; the development of a local user group and a local user network; and an internet-based forum (a ‘virtual group’).

 

The project demonstrated that:

people with MND and their carers have extensive knowledge and experience through which MND policy and service provision can be improved.  Participants expressed the wish to be more involved in all aspects of service planning and delivery.

BUILD identified the need to involve users in the development of an improved model of care.

People affected by MND are often required to organise their own packages of care but, paradoxically, the time and effort required to do this can prejudice their quality of life and their involvement in social and community activity.

Contrary to expectations, many of the people with MND who chose to participate in the local group were severely disabled.

The younger and more recently diagnosed people with MND chose to maintain an arm’s-length involvement with the project through a local user network.

It is possible to involve sections of the UK-wide MND community through developing and sustaining an internet-based virtual forum.

One outcome was that users confidently challenged professionals to justify the medical profession’s right to bar access to unproven treatments by people who are terminally ill.

There are indications that younger people with MND find communication via the internet a particularly accessible and appropriate medium for exchanging advice and information, campaigning, and debating issues relating to clinical trials and other research activity.

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,OLDER PEOPLE,PEOPLE WITH MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES,CARERS,COMMISSIONING,SERVICE SECTORS,COMMUNITY AND DOMICILIARY SERVICES,SOCIAL CARE,ASSESSMENT AND PLANNING,SERVICE PROVISION,SERVICE DEVELOPMENT,POPULATIONS SERVED,PATIENT AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT,COMMUNICATION,DISEASE/CONDITION GROUPS,MENTAL HEALTH PROBLEMS,OLDER PEOPLE,COMMISSIONING PROCESS]]>
document.body: This factsheet aims to help those who are involved in planning, developing, commissioning and providing services in the health, social care, housing, private and voluntary sectors for older people with functional mental illness. It can be used across health and social care systems to facilitate discussion about how to involve people and their carers in the development and provision of services; it outlines why people need to be involved and identifies a range of different ways to do so. The examples used may be adapted to meet local need.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Involving young people in health service development
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH,YOUNG PEOPLE,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,YOUNG PEOPLE,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,DECISION MAKING,POPULATIONS,GROUPS,AGE GROUPS]]>
document.body:
Increasing attention is being paid to involving NHS patients, including young people, in local service development. However, we know little about the views and experiences of young patients, especially those with a chronic illness or physical disability who have wide experience of health services, which could inform how best to include them in developing services. This project investigated how the NHS currently consults with this group, and sought to identify factors which could support and promote young patients’ involvement in service development.

]]>

document.body:
Concerns about the democratic process and a wide range of specific policy initiatives (such as Best Value, Connexions and the Neighbourhood Renewal Strategy) have led many local authorities to look at ways of enhancing young people's involvement in local decision-making. A study carried out by the Institute for Public Policy Research explored the challenges that local authorities may face when seeking to involve young people in local governance and potential solutions. This document is a summary of the report ‘Up for it: getting young people involved in local government’ published by IPPR, in 2002.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: invoNET Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
The invoNET library has been developed for people with an interest in research into public involvement in research. It includes references (reports and articles) that cover:

the impact of public involvement on research
the nature and extent of public involvement in research, e.g. mapping public involvement
reflections on public involvement in research

It also includes other pieces of work that shed new light or provide a new perspective on public involvement in research.

It does not include case studies or descriptions of good practice. Reports of research projects where the public have been involved are only included if they contain a substantial amount of critical analysis or substantial reflection on the impact or the nature of involvement.

While the main focus is on public involvement in NHS, public health and social care research, studies of service user involvement in service development are included when the lessons can be generalised.

The library contains journal publications and grey literature (project reports, conference presentations, books and book chapters, theses, editorials in journals), but does not include comments, letters and opinion pieces.

The first 85 entries in the library have been published as Volume One of the library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Joint health scrutiny committees
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,HEALTH SCRUTINY,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This publication focuses on the opportunities and challenges presented by joint health scrutiny. Health overview and scrutiny committees (OSCs) of social services authorities can choose to form joint health OSCs to consider health issues that cross boundaries but they must form joint health OSCs to respond to consultations from the NHS about proposals for developments or variations in health services (affecting people in more than one local authority area) that relevant health OSCs consider to be "substantial". It is important that health OSCs work together to bring the views of their communities into the processes for planning and delivering health services and to work in partnership with the NHS to discuss plans for "substantial" changes at an early stage. It is likely that all health OSCs and NHS bodies will, sooner or later, be involved with a joint health OSC and it is crucial that everyone considers how to make joint health scrutiny arrangements work.

This publication adopts a practical approach. Different stages of the development of joint health OSCs are considered from the legislative and constitutional framework, to planning ahead with health partners and neighbours, to carrying out joint health scrutiny reviews and tackling consultations from the NHS. Wherever possible practical examples are used and contact details given so that readers can find out more about existing practice. Inevitably the contact details will change over time.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Keeping the NHS local : a new direction of travel
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This document aims to help the local NHS to work in a new stronger partnership with the public and staff to find high quality, sustainable solutions for local services, and deliver the agenda for reform. It outlines an approach to local service design and consultation that reflects both the new requirements for partnership, the “closer to home” model of care supported by the National Beds Inquiry and the new opportunities generated by service and workforce modernisation.

 

The guidance proposes sustainable solutions for smaller hospitals to secure their valued role at the heart of local communities. Service and workforce redesign offer the potential for a wider range of safe, effective, high-quality care to be offered in smaller hospitals than has previously been thought possible.

 

These are the three core patient principles to be followed.

• developing options for change with people, not for them, starting from the patient experience and our commitment to improve choice, and working with staff to develop new ways of delivering services;

• focus on redesign not relocate. Redesign can offer a high quality alternative to relocating services, extending the range of options for devoping new configurations that meet local needs and expectations;

• taking a whole systems view: the NHS needs to exploit the contributions of different hospitals, primary, intermediate and social care providers within a whole systems centralising pressures by working in partnership, with genuine integration and joint planning of services.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: KIDMAP, a web based system for gathering patients' feedback on their doctors
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Background
The gathering of feedback on doctors from patients after consultations is an important part of patient involvement and participation. This study first assesses the 23-item Patient Feedback Questionnaire (PFQ) designed by the Picker Institute, Europe, to determine whether these items form a single latent trait. Then, an Internet module with visual representation is developed to gather patient views about their doctors; this program then distributes the individualized results by email.

Methods
A total of 450 patients were randomly recruited from a 1300-bed-size medical center in Taiwan. The Rasch rating scale model was used to examine the data-fit. Differential item functioning (DIF) analysis was conducted to verify construct equivalence across the groups. An Internet module with visual representation was developed to provide doctors with the patient's online feedback.

Results
Twenty-one of the 23 items met the model's expectation, namely that they constitute a single construct. The test reliability was 0.94. DIF was found between ages and different kinds of disease, but not between genders and education levels. The visual approach of the KIDMAP module on the WWW seemed to be an effective approach to the assessment of patient feedback in a clinical setting.

Conclusion
The revised 21-item PFQ measures a single construct. The authors' work supports the hypothesis that the revised PFQ online version is both valid and reliable, and that the KIDMAP module is good at its designated task. Further research is needed to confirm data congruence for patients with chronic diseases.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Lay perspectives : advantages for health research
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
Although involvement of the consumer is increasingly being advocated in health related research, it is not welcome universally. Furthermore, the underlying rationale is rarely made explicit. Policy makers, health care professionals, and researchers need to be clear about the benefits and ways of including lay perspectives and the criteria for evaluating these. Examples of lay involvement in setting research agendas, methodological debate, and specific projects are accumulating, but little clear evidence about the benefits and costs of different ways of incorporating lay input into health services research is available.

The authors outline two basic reasons for incorporating lay perspectives into research and discuss some common objections. A framework is offered to help clarify the dimensions of lay involvement in health research. The term "lay" is used to mean people who are neither health care professionals nor health services researchers, but who may have specialised knowledge related to health. This includes patients, the general public, and consumer advocates.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Laying the foundations for governors in Hackney
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
In its first three months as a first wave Foundation Trust, the Homerton Hospital came to appreciate that developing a strong Council of Governors meant far more than relying on goodwill. The challenge was to convert the principles of cooperative membership and the legal status of a public benefit corporation into something people in this highly diverse and deprived urban community could identify with and want to influence.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Learning disability partnership boards: are service users really insiders?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,PEOPLE WITH LEARNING DISABILITIES]]>
document.body:
It is now almost six years since the establishment of learning disability partnership boards. Research has found that the partnership between public sector managers and lay members is not on equal terms as defined in the white paper Valuing People. Where primary care trusts cascade learning disability development funding to partnership boards it is possible to provide opportunities for people with learning disabilities to allocate money to enable "bottom up" initiatives to be supported.

]]>

It was hoped that this approach would enable children and young people to talk more freely with young members of staff who had some similar, shared experiences.

document.title: Learning from organisational development : year one
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
This report, published in October 2008, details the results and findings of the NHS Centre for Involvement's Organisational Development Projects across seven sites during the first year of the NCI’s work in 2006-2007. From these projects, themes of good practice have been identified alongside key challenges. The conclusions and recommendations resulting from these projects inform future organisational development work and help to focus the development of further learning and training to support organisations to develop PPI.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Learning from organisational development: a summary of outcomes of patient and public involvement projects across NHS organisations in England
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
This report details the results and findings of Organisational Development Projects across twenty five sites during the second and final years of the NCI’s work in 2007-2009. From these projects, themes of good practice have been identified alongside key challenges. The conclusions and recommendations resulting from these projects inform future organisational development work and help to focus the development of further learning and training to support organisations to develop PPI.

The following areas were noted as being beneficial factors in promoting, planning, undertaking, maintaining, disseminating and reviewing PPI organisational development

 

Senior Managers who are committed to moving the culture of their organization consistently to being patient led.

Trusts that identified and developed further PPI champions at all levels of the organisation, harnessed their enthusiasm and ensured that they were equipped and supported.

Trusts with effective Patient Partnership Managers, PPI Managers or similar were better able to progress the involvement agenda than those without such a lead role.

Trusts that allocated adequate resources at each stage of the involvement cycle. Resources for PPI activity included indirect costs as well as cash benefits. These

included support worker costs, provision of support workers such as translators, administrative space, accessible materials and training costs.

Inclusive processes such as a reimbursement policy for involvement which were considered and formalised.

An integrated PPI strategy that was patient led and board approved and that set out specific actions, expected outcomes and agreed timescales.

Roles and responsibilities which were defined within a communications strategy that was complementary to the PPI strategy with clarity provided about feedback mechanisms and the dissemination/celebration of outcomes.

Trusts with a strong relationship with the voluntary sector, which was used effectively to ensure that local people across a diverse range of cultures had a voice on local health issues.

Trusts that were proactive in going out into the local community to obtain views and establish collaborative PPI networks.

Effective partnership working demonstrated by two way representation e.g. lay members sat on key Trust decision making committees and in turn senior Trust members sat on patient group committees.

Trusts that had a step by step process in place to undertake evaluation of PPI activity involving patients, from planning through to the review stage.

Integrating involvement into staff induction, training and development were key factors to success.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Learning from practice : evaluating a community involvement team within a health action zone
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
The range of activities and the focus on partnership working in Health Action Zones create challenges for evaluation. This paper describes the evaluation of a Health Action Zone initiative aimed at increasing community involvement in health across a health district. The design and implementation of the evaluation have been shaped by the policy context, the diversity of activities and the range of stakeholders from different sectors and communities. A collaborative approach to research has enabled findings to be fed into policy and practice. The paper reflects on the evaluation process and discusses some of the methodological and ethical issues that have arose.

 

This article was originally published in Research Policy and Planning (2001) vol. 19 no. 3.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Learning from the early adopter programme
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM]]>
document.body:
Published in June 2007, this is the interim report for the Local Involvement Network Early Adopter Programme evaluation. The report describes learning gathered since the introduction of the programme from January 2007 until the end of June 2007.

 

This report provides an introduction to the programme which is testing out a new model of public involvement in health and social care across nine Early Adopter Programme sites. It highlights the links between this report, which provides an interim gathering of learning of seven of the EAP sites (funded by the Commission for Patient and Public Involvement in Health) and the report written by the Office of People Management, which is leading the evaluation of the two EAP sites (funded by the Healthcare Commission).]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Learning lessons from thematic social inclusion partnerships (SIPs)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Social inclusion partnerships (SIPs) were a key part of the Scottish Executive’s Social Justice policy agenda in the late 1990s. The SIP approach saw the introduction of new thematic partnerships which focused on the social exclusion of particular social groups, as well as an expansion in the number of area-based partnerships which targeted the most deprived communities in Scotland.

This report, published in January 2007, identifies the lessons which emerged from the practices of thematic SIPs, and finds that a range of distinct practices emerged within many of the thematic SIPs that differed from the approaches and rationale informing the work of area-based SIPs.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Learning the lessons from PALS : a report on the findings of a qualitative study to evaluate the introduction of Patient Advice and Liaison Services in London
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Patient Advice and Liaison Services (PALS) were introduced throughout England in all National Health Service and Primary Care Trusts. They formed part of a wider Patient and Public Involvement (PPI) initiative to empower patients and strengthen patient choice. PALS are intended to provide service users with an identifiable person to whom they can turn if they have a problem or need for information or advice. Additionally PALS are meant to link with vulnerable and 'hard to reach' groups, and act as a 'catalyst for change' and improvement in host trusts. PALS were set up at a time of change in the health service. Other PPI initiatives included the abolition of Community Health Councils; the establishment of locally based Independent Complaints Advocacy Services to support individuals using the formal NHS complaints system; and in each NHS and Primary Care Trust, the creation of a Patient and Public Involvement Forum (PPIF), to monitor and comment on local NHS services.

 

This research had two key aims:

 

to identify and share the lessons learnt from the establishment and development of London PALS

 

to develop acceptable user-centred criteria by which to judge the success of PALS

 

Data for this longitudinal study were gathered using a variety of qualitative methods between April 2002 and June 2004.

 

The study found that service users and trust staff both appear to like the services offered, and feel that PALS provide a highly appreciated 'friendly face' and clear point of access and coordination for enquiries within trusts (as well as across wider health and social care interfaces). In particular, people are impressed that PALS appear to help resolve individual's concerns more promptly than previous available options (such as directly contacting clinical staff, or negotiating the formal complaints system).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Learning to listen : core principles for the involvement of children and young people
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,CHILDREN,YOUNG PEOPLE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
The Government wants children and young people to have more opportunities to get involved in the design, provision and evaluation of policies and services that affect them or which they use. Ministers will be looking to their individual departments and agencies to develop robust but realistic arrangements to make sure this happens.  Actively involving children and young people in this way will produce better services.  Ultimately that will produce better outcomes for children and young people, as well as stronger communities, as departments and agencies across government draw on children and young people’s contributions to shape and tailor services to meet real, rather than presumed needs.

 

The purpose of this guidance is to:

 

• introduce the core principles on which this work should be based;

• provide departments with some early advice and background and with signposts to additional help, so that departments can develop effective plans and

• let departments know the broad timetable for action.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Learning to take control
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,SELF MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
The author looks at the self management course which Arthritis Care has been running for ten years.  They are taught by people with arthritis who share their expertise in living with the condition and developing coping strategies.

 

This article is reproduced on the Expert Patients Programme web site.  It was originally published in Arthritis News, issue 117 (February/March 2005).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Learning together : further lessons from health scrutiny in action
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,HEALTH SCRUTINY]]>
document.body:
Each year between 2004 and 2006, the Centre for Public Scrutiny (CfPS) invited health overview and scrutiny committees to bid for funding to support action learning in health scrutiny, with a focus on health inequalities. Each project was awarded up to £20,000. A report about the first nine action learning projects, called Sharing the Learning - Lessons from Health Scrutiny in Action was published in October 2006. This report, published in June 2007, reflects on the learning from the second round of action learning projects.

In round 2, overview and scrutiny committees (OSCs) were asked to submit bids around the key themes in the 'Choosing Health' white paper. The successful bids were chosen for their potential to generate lessons and best practice for health OSCs and the NHS across the country

This report provides a summary of the processes, achievements and lessons experienced through action learning in health scrutiny reviews. Action learning was used in these sites as a mechanism to 'learn through experience' using sharing and reflection in order to make the learning explicit. The project leads were required to report on their progress as they progressed through the scrutiny review, noting what had worked well and what not so well, what they had gained most and what they would have done differently with the benefit of hindsight.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Lessons from a patient partnership intervention to prevent adverse drug events.
document.publisher: International Journal for Quality in Healthcare
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES,SHARED DECISION MAKING,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PARTICIPATION,PARTNERSHIP]]>
document.body:
BACKGROUND: Patient safety 'best practices' that call for patient participation to prevent adverse drug events have not been rigorously evaluated. OBJECTIVE: To consider lessons learned from a patient partnership intervention to prevent adverse drug events among medical in-patients. DESIGN: Prospective randomized, controlled pilot trial. SETTING: Boston teaching hospital. Patients. Two hundred and nine adult in-patients on a general medicine unit. INTERVENTION: Intervention patients (n = 107) received drug safety information and their medication list; controls (n = 102) received drug safety information only. Measurements. Adverse drug events and close-call drug errors were identified using chart review and incident reports from nurses, pharmacists, and physicians. Patients and clinicians were surveyed about the intervention. RESULTS: In 1053 patient-days at risk, 11 patients experienced 12 adverse drug events and 16 patients experienced 18 close calls. There was a non-significant difference between intervention patients and controls in survey responses and in the adverse drug event rate (8.4% versus 2.9%, P = 0.12) and close-call rate (7.5% versus 9.8%, P = 0.57). Eleven percent of patients were aware of drug-related mistakes during the hospitalization. Among nurse respondents, 29% indicated that at least one medication error was prevented when a patient or family member identified a problem. CONCLUSION: Partnering with in-patients to prevent adverse drug events is a promising strategy but requires further study to document its efficacy.

The article can be cited as International Journal for Quality in Health Care 2004 16 (6): 499-507.

]]>

document.description: A guide to involving lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people in community planning
document.body: This guide aims to give a brief introduction to some of the challenges faced in involving lesbian, gay, bisexual and trangender (LGBT) people, and some suggestions for overcoming these barriers. This guide has been developed in consultation with local planning departments and LGBT organisations, and it aims to provide an LGBT slant on the National Standards for Community Engagement, focusing in particular on practical, concrete suggestions for better engagement.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Limits to patient choice : example from anaesthesia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE]]>
document.body:
This article summarises the results of a survey and textual analysis of materials gathered from 267 anaesthetic departments in the United Kingdom as part of the Royal College of Anaesthetists’ patient information project. It concludes that acknowledging the uncertainties about the advisability of pre-operative fasting should foster a relationship of mutual confidence and respect and allow patients to understand why some choices might not be available to them.

 

This article was published in BMJ Vol 326 19 April 2003

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: LINks and their PCTs
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM]]>
document.body:
LINks are gradually developing the capacity to influence primary care trusts, the bodies responsible for commissioning most health services for populations in their area. This research was designed to assess the degree to which LINks had developed high level engagement with board members – the PCTs’ principal decision-makers.

The data presented in this report was obtained from PCT chief executives. Of 135 respondents to the survey of 148 PCTs, 98 reported that LINks attended meetings of the board (73%) and that all 98 were sent agendas and documents for the board meeting. Out of those LINKs that attended board meetings, PCTs reported that 60% sat round the table with board members (44% of all PCT respondents) and that all had full speaking rights throughout the meeting (as for board members). Only one LINk representative attended PCT board meetings and had full speaking rights without sitting with PCT's board members. A small number of LINks (6) attended the private Part 2 sessions of board meetings. Most PCTs (84%) reported that the arrangements for inclusion of LINks in board meetings were unchanged since the abolition of community health councils and patients’ forums. Many PCTs have developed committee structures to include LINks in the work of board sub-committees and other aspects of their work.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Listen to us : involving people with dementia in planning and developing services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,SERVICE DELIVERY,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This guide, published in 2005, draws on a review of current literature on the involvement of people with dementia, and wider literature on user involvement, to provide an overview of what we know about involving people with dementia in service planning and development. The authors also draw on the practice experience of a range of involvement initiatives, which they describe in detail. However, involving people with dementia remains an innovative and evolving area of work. There are, therefore, many aspects of policy and practice about which they can provide good practice guidance, but few areas in which we can give definitive, evidence-based advice.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Listen up! : effective community consultation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,CONSULTING PATIENTS AND PUBLIC,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This paper aims to help authorities to secure the benefits that consultation can offer and get good value from the resources that they invest in it. This paper concentrates on:

 

 • what consultation is;

• planning consultation;

• overcoming common obstacles to effective consultation;

• the principles of good practice; and

• evaluating effectiveness.

 

The paper concentrates on consulting local people, but the good practice described could also be applied to consultation with businesses, partner organisations or other external bodies.

 

This paper is primarily intended to:

 

• help officers in councils, police authorities, fire authorities and health bodies to plan and carry out community consultation more effectively; and

 

• offer advice to authority members about using community consultation in making policy and improving services.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Living with risk: mental health service user involvement in risk assessment and management
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,PEOPLE WITH MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES]]>
document.body:
This research is about the involvement in risk assessment and management of those mental health service users considered by professionals to pose a potential risk to other people. The research was carried out because of concerns that the voices of such service users were not being heard in research, policy or practice. The overall aim is to produce recommendations for good practice that enable the expertise of this largely hidden group to be included in the planning and provision of effective services. It outlines the aims and objectives of the research and then describes the context of increasing concern about dangerousness within which it took place, a fact noted by the following service user, who also identified more salient risk factors than mental state, namely age and gender: “But, again, from the kind of general voice of users who say ‘Well, actually, most of us find that a little bit kind of strong to somehow say because one’s had mental health problems, you’re immediately at risk to the public’.... And so, you know, to put it in context, all those lads out on Saturday nights supporting England are probably much more of a risk to the general public than I am with my mental health difficulties.”

The lack of research exploring the views of service users defined as a risk to others is also highlighted. Finally, the report describes details of the criteria developed to find a sample of service users and details of how the authors wrote up the research to preserve anonymity and confidentiality.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local area agreements and the third sector : public service delivery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,SERVICE DELIVERY,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Local authorities should work more collaboratively with voluntary and community organisations to help them improve the delivery of public services, according to this report from the National Audit Office.

 

The report looks at whether Local Area Agreements (LAAs) are helping to promote better value for money in the way government works with the third sector to deliver public services. It also examined the impact LAAs have had on the role of third sector organisations in the delivery of public services.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local authority health overview and scrutiny committees and patient and public involvement forums : working together : a practical guide
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,HEALTH SCRUTINY,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
A new guide published in June 2005 by the Centre for Public Scrutiny (CfPS)  for health overview and scrutiny committees (OSCs) and patient and public involvement forums (PPIFs). The guide clarifies the distinct roles of OSCs and PPIFs and suggests ways that they can work together to maximise their influence on decisions about health and healthcare.

The guide is part of the package of measures to provide further support for patient and public involvement that was announced by the Minister for Health Services in June.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local control and local variation in the NHS: what do the public think?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ The move towards greater local autonomy in the NHS offers new possibilities for services that are specifically targeted at local needs. Locally varied services will be necessary to make the health service more effective and efficient in the years ahead. But there are fears that greater local spending and decision-making power will undermine the national character of the NHS, amid public concern about ‘postcode lotteries’. This study presents the findings of a piece of original research carried out in conjunction with Ipsos MORI examining public views about variation in the NHS.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007
document.topics: <![CDATA[ POLICY,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,LEGISLATION,INTRODUCTION TO PPI]]>
document.body:
This is an Act to make provision with respect to local government and the functions and procedures of local authorities and certain other authorities; to make provision with respect to persons with functions of inspection and audit in relation to local government; to establish the Valuation Tribunal for England; to make provision in connection with local involvement networks; to abolish Patients’ Forums and the Commission for Patient and Public Involvement in Health; to make provision with respect to local consultation in connection with health services; and for connected purposes.

 

The paragraphs relating to patient and public involvement in health and social care are as follows:

 

Local involvement networks 

221 Health services and social services: local involvement networks

222 Arrangements under section 221(1)

223 Arrangements: power to make further provision

224 Duties of services-providers to respond to local involvement networks

225 Duties of services-providers to allow entry by local involvement networks

226 Local involvement networks: referrals of social care matters

227 Local involvement networks: annual reports

228 Transitional arrangements

229 Sections 221 to 228: interpretation and supplementary

 

Abolition of Patients’ Forums etc 

230 Abolition of functions of Patients’ Forums

231 Abolition of Patients’ Forums

232 Abolition of Commission for Patient and Public Involvement in Health

 

Consultation about health services

233 Duty to involve users of health services

234 Reports on consultation

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local government scrutiny and health : using the new power to tackle health inequalities
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PPI IN PRACTICE,HEALTH SCRUTINY,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,LOCAL COMMUNITIES,POLICY,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,GOVERNMENT,GOVERNMENT & LAW,COMMUNITIES,POPULATIONS]]>
document.body:
Published in 2003, this report provides eighteen case studies of local authorities’ emerging approaches to health overview and scrutiny. It also summarises the main challenges identified by these authorities in taking forward health scrutiny and their ideas for action. It looks particularly at the ways in which this new local authority power can be used to tackle health inequalities – a joint priority for both the NHS and local government.

 

The case studies present a mixture of types of authorities at different stages in their health scrutiny work, from different parts of the country. Some of the these focus on their arrangements for health scrutiny and the selection of priorities, particularly those from two tier authorities with a large number of scrutiny partners. Others, mainly from unitary and metropolitan boroughs, describe scrutiny exercises underway or completed. In a small number of authorities, health scrutiny has already been running, in shadow form, for several years.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local government using participatory methods to facilitate stakeholder dialogue and conflict resolution
document.publisher: International Institute for Environment and Development
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
Many university cities across Britain face increasing conflicts between residents and students in parts of town favoured by students for accommodation. This paper assesses the way Newcastle City Council tackled the problem using participation to include all involved parties, and to ensure that certain groups or individuals did not dominate the discussion.

 

This article was originally published in PLA Notes 44 June 2002

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local Involvement Networks (LINks)
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - patient and public involvement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM]]>
document.body:
111-1Local Involvement Networks (LINks)
Definition

On 1 April 2008, Patient Forums were replaced by Local Involvement Networks (LINks).
LINks aim to give citizens a stronger voice in how their health and social care services are delivered. Run by local individuals and groups and independently supported - the role of LINks is to find out what people want, monitor local services and to use their powers to hold them to account. LINks were to be established in most areas between April 2008 and September 2008. Each local authority (that provides social services) has been given funding and is under a legal duty to make contractual arrangements that enable LINk activities to take place. (1) Backed up by certain powers, LINks will:

  • provide everyone in the community - from individuals to voluntary groups - with the chance to say what they think about local health and social care services - what is working and what is not.
  • give people the chance to influence how services are planned and run.
  • feedback to services what people have said about services so that things can be improved. (2)

Guidance/Tools

Department of Health
Real involvement: working with people to improve services (30 October 2008)
The NHS duty to involve and consult: Section 242 of the Health and Social Care Act (Modified 20 October 2008)
Listening and responding to communities: a brief guide to Local Involvement Networks (5 September 2008)

Directions about the arrangements to be made by relevant bodies in respect of Local Involvement Networks 2008 (1 April 2008)
Local Involvement Networks: briefing for independent providers (1 April 2008)

Centre for Public Scrutiny
Ten questions to ask if you're scrutinising arrangements to support Local Involvement Networks (April 2009)

Healthcare Commission (now part of Care Quality Commission)

NHS Centre for Involvement

1. Summary - Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007

3. What LINks mean for: Local Authorities

5. Procuring a host to support LINks
6. Transfer of Undertakings (TUPE)
7. Transitional arrangements for LINks
8. Making people aware of LINks
9. Getting going - the first ten things that LINks should do
10. Setting a work programme
11. Accountability and Transparency
12. Governance
13. Working with Volunteers
14. Annual Reports
14. Annual Reports Appendix: Directions on Annual Reports
15. Checking Progress
16. Community Development
17. LINks and Overview and Scrutiny Committees working together
18. Health and Social Care structures
19. Working with LINks

Local Involvement Networks: explaining the role of the NHS Centre for Involvement (February 2008)

Reports and Consultation Documents

Patient and public involvement in the NHS (BMA, March 2008)

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local Involvement Networks : briefing for independent providers
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM]]>
document.body:
From 1 April 2008, Local Involvement Networks (LINks) will be established to find out what citizens want from local services, monitor and review the care they provide and to tell those who run and commission services what the community thinks. To help LINks carry out their role, the legislation establishing them gives LINks certain powers - such as being able to enter and view services under certain safeguards. This briefing explains more about LINks and the implications for independent providers of health and social care services.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local Involvement Networks : explaining the role of the NHS Centre for Involvement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM]]>
document.body:
The Department of Health has asked the NHS Centre for Involvement (NCI) to be the lead organisation for supplying advice and guidance about LINks. There are three strands of work taking place:

  • practical advice, guidance and support;
  • voluntary and community sector fieldwork; and
  • LINks Exchange (IT portal).

The NCI has prepared this document which explains some of their project plans.

 

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Local Involvement Networks : learning from the Early Adopter Programme : final report
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM]]>
document.body:
This is the final report for the Local Involvement Network Early Adopter Programme evaluation, published in November 2007. The report describes learning gathered since the introduction of the programme from January 2007 until the end of September 2007.

 

Section 1 provides an introduction to the programme which was testing out a new model of public involvement in health and social care across nine Early Adopter Programme sites. The authors highlight the links between this report, which provides an interim gathering of learning of seven of the EAP sites (funded by the Commission for Patient and Public Involvement in Health) and the report written by the Office of People Management, which is leading the evaluation of two EAP sites (funded by the Healthcare Commission).

 

Section 2 provide details of the context of the evaluation, including a summary of the evaluation framework and the way that the learning for this report was gathered. More detailed papers have been produced to support the evaluation framework and the methodology and are also available on www.nhscentreforinvolvement.nhs.uk.

 

Section 3 summarises the key learning from the Early Adopter Programme (EAP) derived from the seven sites supported by the Commission for Patient and Public Involvement in Health (CPPIH) and from other activities such as the nine Regional Events, the Local Government Workshops and national meetings.

 

Section 4 summarises the conclusions reached by the Early Adopter Programme.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: London Patient Choice Project Evaluation : a model of patients’ choices of hospital from stated and revealed preference choice data
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,SERVICE DELIVERY,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This joint study by RAND Europe, the King's Fund and City University reveals that patients are more likely to choose to be treated at a hospital with a good reputation rather than one that has shorter waiting times. Patients who were surveyed for the study were also willing to trade off longer waits for operations if the NHS was prepared to pay for and arrange travel.

The findings are based on an evaluation of the London Patients Choice Project (LPCP) - one of the first government schemes to offer patients on waiting lists quicker access to hospital treatment. The project was established in June 2002 and ran until March 2004, with patients first being offered a choice in October 2002. During this period 22,500 patients were offered choice in five specialties covering 35 operations. Of these, 15,000 patients accepted treatment at another hospital rather than their local one. Their care was paid for by the LPCP.

The study found that less wealthy patients are more willing to accept being treated at hospitals with a poor reputation. and also identified the lack of existing information available to patients on hospital reputation to help patients make informed choice.

Finally, the research finds that the Government's decision not to pay, or at least organise, patient transport to hospitals beyond their local area will reduce the range of opportunities for patients to exercise choice in some cases.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Looking after me : evaluating a new self management course for carers : a report for the Expert Patients Programme and the Long Term Medical Conditions Alliance
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,SELF MANAGEMENT,CARERS]]>
document.body:
This report, published in August 2004 for the Expert Patients Programme and the Long Term Medical Conditions Alliance provides an evaluation of a new self management course for carers, 'Looking After Me'.  

Key Points

 

§         The course has real benefits for carers and can help them develop the confidence and motivation to use their own skills to take more effective control of their lives

 

§         The evaluation suggests that the course can also benefit the people being cared for, as carers share skills and techniques and relationships are improved

 

§         These two findings (above) suggest that the development of a carers’ self-management course would complement and add value to the mainstream CDSM programme

 

§         The evaluation suggests that minor modifications to the content and wording of the course may make the course more relevant to carers

 

§         Practical issues, such as publicity, respite costs, length and timing of sessions, venue, refreshments, group size and follow-up of non-attenders, all have an impact on the effectiveness and take-up of the course

 

It is recommended that the course should be made widely available once the changes to content and structure have been addressed.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Looking out from the middle: user involvement in health and social care in Northern Ireland
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
This report, published in February 2008, looks across health and social care services for children, young people and adults with four aims:

 

  1. To provide a short summary of the history and principles of user involvement.
  2. To describe the current situation in Northern Ireland.
  3. To discuss a range of options for the further inclusion and participation of users in the work of the Northern Ireland Social Care Council (NISCC), the Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority (RQIA) and the Social Care Institute of Excellence (SCIE).
  4. To make recommendations to inform the development of a future strategy for users
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Lost in translation : (mis)understanding youth engagement : synthesis report : charting the course for youth civic and political participation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This publication analyses and expands upon six individual studies commissioned by the Canadian Policy Research Network since it held a "National Youth Dialogue and Summit" in 2005. The central finding is that 'Generation Y' – those born after 1979 – is far from apathetical and apolitical. However, while very much tuned into small "p" political life, young Canadians are increasingly disenchanted with formal political institutions and politics as currently practiced.

]]>

document.title: Making a difference: management of chronic pain: improving shared decision making in osteoarthritis
