document.body:
This Guide, published in 2008, is designed as a practical resource for health care organisations that are striving to become more patient-centred. It contains best practices and practical implementation tools contributed by hospitals from across the United States. The Self-Assessment Tool can help identify and prioritise opportunities for introducing patient-centred approaches into an organisation.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Patient-centered care: what does it take?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Patient-centered care has become a central aim for the USA's health system, yet patient experience surveys indicate that the system is far from achieving it. Based on interviews with leaders of patient-centered organizations and initiatives, this report identifies seven key factors for achieving patient-centered care at the organization level: 1) top leadership engagement, 2) a strategic vision clearly and constantly communicated to every member of the organization, 3) involvement of patients and families at multiple levels, 4) a supportive work environment for all employees, 5) systematic measurement and feedback, 6) the quality of the built environment, and 7) supportive information technology. The report illustrates how these factors can be successfully implemented through case examples of two organizations, MCG Health System in Georgia and Bronson Methodist Hospital in Michigan. The report concludes with a discussion of strategies at the organization and system level that can help leverage widespread implementation of patient-centered care.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Patients' experience of CHD choice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,SERVICE DELIVERY,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Research undertaken for the Department of Health by health care research organisation Picker Institute Europe, showed that almost 90% of patients who took part would definitely recommend the Coronary Heart Disease (CHD) Choice initiative to others waiting for the same operation.

 

Twenty-eight NHS Trusts participated in the programme, offering coronary heart disease patients who faced a wait of more than six months for heart surgery, the opportunity to choose to be treated more quickly elsewhere.

 

Half of the 2,525 patients given a choice opted to go elsewhere, and the Picker Institute was tasked with finding out what factors influenced the decisions they made and obtaining feedback on their experiences.  It is the first time that research has been carried out on patients who have actually been given the option of treatment at an alternative hospital, as opposed to a hypothetical situation.

 

Researchers found that there were three critical elements to the successful uptake of the programme:

·         the provision of enough information to allow patients to make an informed choice about whether to stay at their ‘home’ hospital or go elsewhere

·         reassurance about the continuity of care from local health professionals once they had returned home

·         concerns about the length of time taken to travel to the alternative hospital, both for the patient themselves and family and friends who want to visit

 

In addition, the research showed that Patient Care Advisors, whose role was to support patients taking part in the Choice programme, were highly valued, particularly by those patients who chose to go elsewhere for treatment.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Patients' experience of choosing where to undergo surgical treatment : evaluation of London Patient Choice scheme
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,SERVICE DELIVERY,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
The London Patient Choice Project was established in June 2002 and ran until March 2004. Patients were first offered choice in October 2002.  During the whole period a total of 22,500 patients had been offered choice for 35 operations or procedures in five specialties – ophthalmology, orthopaedics, ENT, urology and general surgery - and 15,000 had accepted treatment at another hospital rather than their local one.

 

Researchers for the Picker Institute sent questionnaires to patients of five London Trusts before they were offered a choice and after their operation. In-depth interviews were also carried out with a smaller group. A total of 2,144 patients (54 per cent response) filled in their Before Surgery questionnaire. Of those sent an After Surgery questionnaire, 977 (53 per cent response) returned the form.

 

No fewer than 97 per cent of patients who opted to go to an alternative hospital said they would recommend the scheme to others. Patients treated at alternative hospitals were significantly more satisfied with their hospital experience than those treated at their home hospital. And patients who were treated in specially designed `treatment centres’ or in private hospitals were more positive than those whose surgery took place in a conventional NHS theatre.

 

However, fewer than a third (32 per cent) of potentially eligible patients were actually offered choice. The five hospitals from which patients were surveyed varied significantly in the proportion of patients offered choice, from 14 to 42 per cent. Of those offered choice two thirds (67 per cent) chose to go to an alternative hospital. Employed people were more likely to make the choice than unemployed but there was no evidence of inequality relating to social class, educational attainment, income or ethnic group.

 

Among the factors influencing the choice that patients made were that the hospital referred to had a high success rate for this operation, that it had a high standard of cleanliness and that there was good communication between the hospital and the patient’s GP. Other factors were the reputation of the surgeon and the hospital, the option of follow-up care closer to home, shorter waiting times and transport and travel issues.

 

Patients considering the offer of an alternative hospital placed hospital cleanliness very high in their list of priorities, with 86 per cent saying it would be a very important factor in deciding where to be treated.

This report was published in July 2005.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Patients for patient safety
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT SAFETY]]>
document.description: A World Health Organization programme
document.body:
Patients for Patient Safety (PFPS), emphasizes the central role patients and consumers can play in efforts to improve the quality and safety of healthcare around the world.

Through the work of PFPS, the World Alliance for Patient Safety collaborates with a global network of patients, consumers, caregivers, and consumer organizations to support patient involvement in patient safety programmes both within countries and in the global programme of the Alliance.

The ultimate purpose is to improve health care safety in all health care settings throughout the world by involving consumers and patients as partners.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Patients' preferences for involvement in treatment decision making in Japan
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,SHARED DECISION MAKING,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Background

A number of previous studies have suggested that the Japanese have few opportunities to participate in medical decision-making, as a result both of entrenched physician paternalism and national characteristics of dependency and passivity. The hypothesis that Japanese patients would wish to participate in treatment decision-making if adequate information were provided, and the decision to be made was clearly identified, was tested by interview survey.

Methods

The subjects were diabetic patients at a single outpatient clinic in Kyoto. One of three case study vignettes (pneumonia, gangrene or cancer) was randomly assigned to each subject and, employing face-to-face interviews, the subjects were asked what their wishes would be as patients, for treatment information, participation in decision-making and family involvement.

Results

134 patients participated in the study, representing a response rate of 90%. The overall proportions of respondents who preferred active, collaborative, and passive roles were 12%, 71%, and 17%, respectively. Respondents to the cancer vignette were less likely to prefer an active role and were more likely to prefer family involvement in decision-making compared to non-cancer vignette respondents. If a physician's recommendation conflicted with their own wishes, 60% of the respondents for each vignette answered that they would choose to respect the physician's opinion, while few respondents would give the family's preference primary importance.

Conclusion

Our study suggested that a majority of Japanese patients have positive attitudes towards participation in medical decision making if they are fully informed. Physicians will give greater patient satisfaction if they respond to the desire of patients for participation in decision-making.

This article was published in BMC Family Practice 2004, 5:1.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Patients' rights and citizens' empowerment: through visions to reality
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
Many countries, including central and eastern European states, are following with great interest the outcomes and impact of the Nordic experience with patients’ rights and citizens’ empowerment: what are the benefits and possible side-effects, how is patient and professional satisfaction influenced, what are the possible links to the current debate on priority-setting and cost-containment, are just a few of the interesting questions raised throughout Europe.

This meeting’s objective was to bring an update of the development of patients’ rights in Europe and draw a plan of action for future activities of the network. It also aimed at identifying new areas for collaboration and new methodologies for promoting patients’ rights, based on the principles of the Declaration on the Promotion of Patients’ Rights (1994) and the Ljubljana Charter on Reforming Health Care (1996).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Patients with complex chronic diseases : perspectives on supporting self-management
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,SELF MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
A Complex Chronic Disease (CCD) is a condition involving multiple morbidities that requires the attention of multiple health care providers or facilities and possibly community (home)-based care. A patient with CCD presents to the health care system with unique needs, disabilities, or functional limitations. The literature on how to best support self-management efforts in those with CCD is lacking. With this paper, the authors present the case of an individual with diabetes and end-stage renal disease who is having difficulty with self-management. The case is discussed in terms of intervention effectiveness in the areas of prevention, addiction, and self-management of single diseases. Implications for research are discussed.

The article was published in J Gen Intern Med. 2007 December; 22(Suppl 3): 438–444.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: People and participation : how to put citizens at the heart of decision making
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES]]>
document.body:
Although participation has become an essential ingredient in public policy decision-making and delivery, the potential and pitfalls of participation in practice are not widely understood. This guidance is intended to be an exploration of the issues facing participatory practice in Britain today, outlining in particular the challenges and opportunities of introducing participatory approaches into its institutions and organisations.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: People and participation.net
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ORGANISATIONS SUPPORTING PPI,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES]]>
document.description: A website providing practical information for those working to involve people
document.body:
Peopleandparticipation.net helps people who work in the public, private and not-for-profit sectors and who need to involve wider groups of people in their work. The site provides information, advice, case studies and opportunities to share experiences with others; aiming to make public participation activities as effective as possible.

 

Peopleandparticipation.net has a number of practical functions:

Process Planner

This is a search engine for participatory methods. It is designed for users who are in the stage of planning for participation. The process planner presents the enquirer with a series of questions and recommends participatory methods based on their answers. The process planner also features supporting information and check-lists that can be used when planning and setting up a participation process.

Methods

This section of the site features detailed and concise information about over thirty of the most popular and successful methods used in public participation. The section is aimed at all users, both those looking for general information and practitioners looking for detailed information on particular participation methods. For further information about a specific method, contact details are available for organisations who invented or regularly practice the method. The methods included are:

21st century town meeting
appreciative inquiry
area forums
blogs
citizen advisory groups
citizens’ panels
citizens’ summits
citizens’ jury
consensus conference
conversation cafes
coproduction
customer journey mapping
deliberative mapping
deliberative polling
deliberative workshops
Delphi survey
democs
design charrettes
dialogue
e-petitions
focus groups
forum theatre
future search
mystery shopper
online consultation
online forums
open space
opinion polls
participatory appraisal
participatory budgeting
participatory strategic planning
planning for real
user panels
Webchat
wiki
world cafe

Case Studies
This section of the site contains examples of successful participatory practice and is for users who are researching or planning for participation. The selection of case studies showcases good practice across the participation spectrum. Contact details accompany each case study. Users can upload their own cases to the site.

 

News and Events
The news and events section contains up to date news feeds (RSS feeds) from a variety of sources , all of which are relevant to participation. An interactive calendar allows those in the participation field to publicise their own events and anything else they feel might interest users of the site.

Ask An Expert
This section allows site users to post their questions about participation. Involve staff will respond to these questions on the site and over time we will collectively create an ever growing knowledge bank of answers to common questions. This section of the site is run as a pilot and users are guaranteed a response to any participation related question sent via this mechanism.

Participation Library
The participation library is a collection of written and web-based resources from around the world to help site users make sense of public participation. Registered site users can upload relevant links that the find useful to the site.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: People's perceptions of their neighbourhood and community involvement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This report presents findings from the social capital module of the General Household Survey (GHS) 2000/01. This work was commissioned by the Health Development Agency (HDA) as part of a larger body of research designed to further understanding of social capital in terms of its meaning, measurement and links to health within the context of a British population. The aim of the GHS module was to develop a new set of national indicators relating to the social environment in which people live. The module was developed to encourage the collection of a standard set of information on social capital which would allow comparisons to be made between different local studies and corresponding national indicators. This report presents the findings from the 2000/01 survey.

 

The main indicators of social capital tend to include:

¦ Social relationships and social support.

¦ Formal and informal social networks.

¦ Group memberships.

¦ Community and civic engagement.

¦ Norms and values.

¦ Reciprocal activities (eg. child care arrangements).

¦ Levels of trust in others.

 

Recent evidence suggests that social approaches to the organisation and delivery of public health may have considerable potential for improvement, particularly for those that suffer most disadvantage in society. The concept of social capital is a relatively new addition to the health field. It has grown out of the recognition that health related behaviours are shaped and constrained by a range of social and community contexts and that the ways in which an individual relates to social networks and communities has important effects on their health and well being. The HDA (previously the Health Education Authority) initiated a number of early exploratory studies to assess the notion of social capital and its links to health. These studies suggested that social capital could play a useful role in helping understanding of the extent to which community level relationships and networks might impact on health in local communities, while appreciating that any such analyses should adjust for a range of sociodemographic indicators.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Perceptions of healthcare : a survey of patient organizations' concerns
document.publisher: International Institute for Environment and Development
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ORGANISATIONS SUPPORTING PPI,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
The following report summarises the UK findings of a survey of perceptions on key healthcare policy issues among patients’ organization members in Europe, Canada and Nigeria. The study was commissioned by the International Alliance of Patients’ Organizations (IAPO), a global alliance representing 365 million patients across all disease areas around the world. It was conducted by Consensus Research Group and supported by Pfizer Inc.

 

The report was commissioned in order to provide an objective insight into patients’ organization members’ perceptions on the state of healthcare, future concerns, and reactions to government healthcare policies.

 

This perception study includes measurement and analysis of the quality of healthcare, the outlook for improvement and tries to identify the major challenges to achieving these improvements. It also reveals the key role that patients’ organizations play in providing information to patients.

 

The study provides evidence of strongly shared views among members of patients’ organizations on needs and concerns related to currently administered healthcare, and signals a need for a shift to a more patient-centred approach.

 

A patient-centred approach aims to better align national healthcare systems with the needs and expectations of patients, notably by improving their access to treatment and information, ensuring participation in healthcare decision- making and involvement in policy-making.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Performance reporting for consumers : issues for the Australian private hospital sector
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,MONITORING AND QUALITY ASSURANCE]]>
document.body:
A group of consumers of private hospital services and their carers collaborated with staff of a Melbourne private hospital and with industry representatives to develop a consumer-driven performance report on cardiac services. During the development process participating consumers identified situational and structural barriers to their right to be informed of costs, to choice and to quality care. Their growing appreciation of these barriers led them to a different perspective on performance reporting, which resulted in their redirecting the project. The consumer participants no longer wanted a performance report that provided comparative quantitative data. Instead they designed a report that outlined the structures, systems and processes the hospital had in place to address the quality and safety of services provided. In addition, consumer participants developed a decision support tool for consumers to use in navigating the private health care sector. The journey of these consumers in creating a consumer driven performance report for a private hospital service may assist those responsible for governance of Australia's health system in choosing appropriate strategies and mechanisms to enhance private hospital accountability. The situational and institutional industry barriers to choice, information and quality identified by these consumers need to be addressed before public performance reporting for private hospitals is introduced in Australia.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Personal health budgets
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE,DIRECT PAYMENTS]]>
document.description: A page on the Department of Health website linking to news and information on personal health budgets
document.body: <![CDATA[ High Quality Care for All announced that from 2009 there will be a pilot, building on experience with individual budgets in social care, to test personal health budgets as a way of giving people greater control over the services they use. Seventy five primary care trusts, in 68 sites, have been awarded provisional pilot status. The pilot programme is now underway and will run for three years until 2012. This section contains news and information about personal health budgets, and links to other websites where more information can be found.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Personal health information management : consumers' perspectives
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
Personal health information management (PHIM) refers to activities that support consumers’ access, integration, organization, and use of their personal health information. The authors investigated PHIM in the health consumer population using a focus group and participatory design. In collaboration with health consumers, they identified PHIM activities and explored the design of new supportive technology. Our findings describe prominent PHIM activities such as monitoring and assessing health, as well as health-related decision making, planning, and action. We describe design principles our participants used during the participatory design of a PHIM tool. These include individual control, sharing, integration, security and flexibility. These findings provide new insights into emerging ideas in consumer health informatics research and technology design. Understanding health consumers’ PHIM needs is an important step in creating technology to support these needs.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Personalisation and individual budgets: challenge or opportunity?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE,DIRECT PAYMENTS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This paper seeks to explore some of the implications of individual budgets for housing providers and commissioners of supported housing. It aims to provide some challenge to the sector to begin weaving choice, control and personalisation throughout their policies, procedures and services to position the sector as the leaders in finding flexible solutions for customers who require assistance, care and support.]]>
