document.title: Personalisation briefing - implications for advocacy workers
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This briefing examines the implications of the personalisation agenda for advocacy workers.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Personalisation good practice: self-directed support at Barnsley Council
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ The author looks at how Barnsley Council are making a success of personalisation through self-directed support.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Personalisation through participation : a new script for public services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This pamphlet published by the think tank Demos, argues that offering personalised education and health services will increase people’s expectations and create a demand-led pressure for reform.

The author believes that if government is serious about personalisation, public sector bodies should regard this promise as a big challenge to the way they currently operate.  He explains how personalisation goes beyond a simple consumer model to actually involving users in their design and delivery of the next generation of services.

This report was produced as part of a Demos project on personalisation with the Innovation Unit of the Department for Education and Skills

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Personalised care, individual budgets, self-directed support: what's the thinking?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE,DIRECT PAYMENTS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This article examines the development of the concepts of personalisation and self-directed support in social care services.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Person-centred planning in social care : a scoping review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Published in 2006, this report explores why and how person-centred planning has spread from learning disability services to influence the whole of adult social care.

 

The study describes how person-centred planning began, discusses the existing evidence base and explains why many practitioners find it an effective way to support people with social care needs. The authors look at the claims for person-centred planning in the context of current policy and service developments. They explore issues relating to service users, their families, frontline staff and implementation of the approach. The report concludes by identifying barriers to person-centred planning and possible ways to overcome them.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Perspectives on the expert patient
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,SELF MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This document is a seminar report from the Royal Pharmaceutical Society's Expert Patient Conference which was held in May 2003. It is a 35-page PDF requiring Adobe Acrobat Reader and comprises six papers given by academics, pharmacists, health professionals and health campaigners. It addresses the concept of the "expert patient" role arising from the changed dynamic between patient/professional by drawing on the personal experiences and researches of the seminar participants. Ease of access to the Internet and other media means that patients are now well-informed consumers who demand greater clarity of shared communication from health professionals. The pros and cons of this patient role vis a vis that of the health professional are examined and the report concludes that careful development and evaluation of the expert patient role are needed if the initiative is to succeed.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Plan with care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,CARERS]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Research has been undertaken to look at how well social care and health organisations involve adult carers in service planning and delivery. This article concludes that while some carers are involved at a strategic level, carers are most dissatisfied about their involvement in individual assessment processes and outcomes.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Planning across the LSP : case studies of integrating community strategies and health improvement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,HEALTH SCRUTINY,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.description: This publication highlights the challenges facing local government, the NHS, police and other LSP partners in working across boundaries, and in aligning their planning systems and partnership arrangements.
document.body:
This report highlights the challenges facing local government, the NHS, police and other LSP partners in working across boundaries, and in aligning their planning systems and partnership arrangements. These challenges and the ideas for action have been identified by LSP, PCT and local authority representatives from around the country, and provide a useful resource for national, regional and local partners.

 

How these challenges are beginning to be addressed is illustrated by the case studies. They demonstrate the commitment and effort being devoted by practitioners at the local level to develop LSPs and partnership working for health and wellbeing. They illustrate a range of locally developed and appropriate approaches to tackling some of the key issues and challenges. It is interesting, for example, to see the: 

Increasing numbers of joint posts across sectors and the emerging arrangements for joint commissioning and service integration across a range of public service functions

Increasing involvement of elected members in cross-sectoral planning

Differing ways in which health scrutiny arrangements are being planned or introduced in a number of areas

Importance attached in a number of case study areas to a more coordinated approach to community involvement.
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Please Ask : the National Patient Safety Agency's website for patients
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT SAFETY]]>
document.body:
The National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA) has previewed to the NHS a new campaign to empower patients to take a more active role in managing their health.

The Please Ask campaign provides practical, accessible information about patient safety and encourages patients to feel comfortable asking questions about their NHS healthcare and raising concerns with health professionals.  It will be rolled out across England and Wales from late March 2006.

The Please Ask website will provide advice structured around the patient journey, with individual tip sheets for outpatients and inpatients as well as for those taking medication, having emergency treatment, and supporting children or elderly relatives in hospital.

Patients can also use the website to share any safety concerns with the NPSA via a new on-line tool, the Patient and Public Reporting e-Form. Although the NPSA does not investigate individual cases or complaints, patients are encouraged to share their experiences so the information can be used to improve safety. They do this by collecting reports on errors and other things that go wrong in healthcare so that they can recognise national trends and introduce practical ways of preventing problems.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Policy on reimbursement and payments to members of the public (including INVOLVE group members) participating in or contributing to INVOLVE's work
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
INVOLVE is committed to the fair involvement of the public in its work. Reimbursement of expenses and payments for time, where appropriate, are one way to help ensure that people have an equal opportunity to participate in INVOLVE’s activities and be acknowledged for any contribution to INVOLVE’s work.

 

Issued in April 2007, this reimbursement and payments policy is relevant to situations where INVOLVE invites members of the public to become involved in its work.

 

The policy tells you:

 

            • when members of the public will receive reimbursement for expenses

 

            • what INVOLVE regard as reasonable expenses

 

            • when other payments, such as for time, will be made

 

            • the individual’s responsibilities in paying tax and national insurance, and what INVOLVE will do

 

            • the individual’s responsibilities when they are receiving state benefits and what INVOLVE will do.

 

The policy will also tell you:

 

            • how claims for reimbursement of expenses can be made

 

            • how claims for payment can be made

 

            • what to expect from INVOLVE when claiming

 

             how long you can expect to wait for reimbursement and payment that is due to you to be made

 

            • what will happen if there is a problem.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Positive participation : consulting and involving young people in health-related work : a planning and training resource
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PPI IN PRACTICE,CONSULTING PATIENTS AND PUBLIC,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,YOUNG PEOPLE,PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,YOUNG PEOPLE,PUBLIC HEALTH,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,DECISION MAKING,MANAGEMENT & POLICY,AGE GROUPS,GROUPS,POPULATIONS]]>
document.body:
The two main aims of Positive Participation are to raise awareness of the need for, and value of, consulting with and involving young people in health-related activities, and to promote more effective consultation and involvement of young people in health-related activities through provision of resource materials and training. This publication works through the relevant issues and provides a range of ideas and tools for successfully involving and consulting young people in health-related activities.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Power in people's hands: learning through the world's best public services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This report presents the findings of a Strategy Unit study of leading edge innovations in world-wide public services, which involved interviewing 50 academics, public servants and other experts from around the world. The report highlights more than 30 case studies from 15 countries. It emphasises that innovation and productivity come from forging stronger relationships with citizens and finds the most successful services have five distinguishing characteristics:

Using entitlements to put power in the hands of users of services
Transforming accountability of services through real time, highly local information
Incentivising the creation of tailor made, integrated, personalised services which citizens can shape
Answering people’s ambition for prevention rather than cure
New professionalism in front-line staff and leaders, with new organisational structures which encourage this.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Power sharing
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body: This article looks at a project where adults and young people, who have experience of the care system, train together as equals. It looks at the effects of the care system on the young people and the impact of adults' perceptions of power. The experience of the project suggests that genuine participation of young people in services holds groundbreaking potential, although joint working has problems.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: PPI case study of user involvement in Sutton and Merton Primary Care Trust
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This is a report on work undertaken by Organisational Development at the NHS Centre for Involvement, to recommend ways of continuing improvement in user involvement at Sutton and Merton Primary Care Trust (PCT).]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: PPI Transition Newsletter
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,INTRODUCTION TO PPI,PPI IN PRACTICE,SERVICE DELIVERY,POLICY,IMPLEMENTATION,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This PPI web page from the Department of Health provides press notices, newsletters, DH and SHA PPI Leads Network meeting notes, and PPI leaflet and poster campaigns.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Practice guidance on involving people with HIV and other long term conditions in planning and developing services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
This paper is intended as a brief practice guide to increasing and supporting the involvement of people with HIV in statutory planning and consultative structures. It is aimed at managers who have responsibility for patient and public involvement of all kinds in primary care trusts, NHS trusts, and local authorities. It focuses particularly on involvement in primary care trusts, since these patient involvement structures are new and recently established in many areas, but the principles it discusses go much wider and many of the approaches are equally applicable to NHS trusts and local authorities. It may also be useful in supporting the involvement of people with other long-term medical conditions, particularly those that are poorly understood or stigmatised within society, such as mental health.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Practice standards in children's participation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,CHILDREN]]>
document.body:
Published in January 2005, this publication provide operational guidance on such issues as:

·         an ethical approach to children's participation

·         the incorporation of child protection concerns into participatory practice

·         the creation of child-friendly environments where all children can participate

·         the importance of follow-up and evaluation.

The practice standards can be used in a variety of ways:

·         to help understand what 'meaningful participation' looks like

·         to improve individual or organisational performance in children's participation

·         to assess the quality of participation as part of a retrospective evaluation

·         to identify skills or knowledge gaps and develop appropriate training.

The set of standards is based on feedback and consultations with Save the Children staff, partner organisations and children in various countries and community settings.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Preventing disability in the elderly with chronic disease
document.publisher: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,EDUCATION FOR PPI,PPI IN PRACTICE,SHARED DECISION MAKING,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,SELF MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Research sponsored by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) in the United States led to the development of the Chronic Disease Self-Management Program (CDSMP), a patient self-management program aiming to prevent or delay disability even in patients with arthritis, heart disease, or hypertension.  These patients were taught how to better manage their symptoms, adhere to medication regimens, and maintain functional ability.  Additional research funded by AHRQ also showed that education and lifestyle changes could reduce disability, control costs, and have a positive influence on the quality of life of America’s elderly.

 

This review, published in April 2002, refers to the NHS adopting the CDSMP as the key educational offering in the Expert Patients Programme.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Preventing infection in hospital - should patient involvement be central to current hand hygiene strategies?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT SAFETY]]>
document.body:
Article Summary

Patient involvement in hand hygiene improvement has not formed a core part of hand hygiene strategies across the NHS.

There is evidence that empowering patients to ask staff about hand hygiene can improve it and reduce infection.

The National Patient Safety Agency has worked with patients and their relatives and carers in the pilot of its ‘cleanyourhands campaign’ and the learning from the pilot informed the next stage of the campaign’s development, with a national launch across the NHS in 2004.

 

This article appears in Clinical Governance Bulletin January 2005 5(5).

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Primary care and public involvement : achieving a balanced partnership
document.publisher: Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ The article, published in January 2000, looks at what lessons primary care groups can learn from the experience of health authorities in involving users and the public. A project based on 75 face to face interviews with health authority staff and advocacy group representatives across twelve health districts suggests that these lessons fall into two categories, the first centres upon organisational factors and the second encompasses issues around implementation.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Primary care cancer leads : working in partnership with cancer patients and carers to improve cancer services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,CARERS,MONITORING AND QUALITY ASSURANCE]]>
document.body:
Published in November 2005, this working brief is designed to provide guidance for Primary Care Cancer Lead clinicians (PCCLs) on ways of working in partnership with patients with cancer and their carers to improve cancer services.

It gives recent examples – from both primary and secondary care – of successful partnership working which have translated into real improvements in care. The examples look at who was involved, and how, and at ways of encouraging real engagement in projects from all involved.

The brief also gives a list of contacts for further information.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Primer on public involvement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
Recently, several trends have brought democratic renewal and public involvement to the forefront of the public agenda. Policy-makers, decision-makers, and researchers are now exploring new approaches to involve the public in democratic decision-making processes in Canada. The purpose of this paper, published in July 2006, is to help inform the deliberations of the Health Council of Canada about the role and parameters of public involvement.

 

Public involvement and democratic governance

Traditionally, public involvement has been broadly defined to include all passive and active forms of involvement in decision-making processes. Most recent efforts tend to synthesize and clarify the concept of public involvement by identifying three main levels of involvement based on the flow of information and interactions between the public and their government: i) public communication; ii) public consultation; and iii) public participation Democratic theory tells us that public involvement can be undertaken for different underlying goals. Indeed, it can be considered as: i) an essential element of a successful democracy; ii) a means for achieving a specific decision outcome; iii) a means for achieving informed, accountable, and legitimate decision-making; iv) a means to contribute to a more educated and engaged citizenry; and v) a means to foster trust and reduce conflicts among stakeholders. However, not everybody is jumping on the public involvement bandwagon. Scholars, policy-makers, decision-makers, and citizens have been apprehensive about participatory models of governance. Despite this, many others are advocating for greater opportunity for public involvement in policy processes.

 

A typology of public involvement methods

The number of public involvement methods has increased exponentially in the literature and in practice. We can classify these methods according to the three levels of public involvement: public communication (e.g. advertisements, publication of reports, newspaper inserts, press releases, news conferences, or websites); public consultation (e.g. public meetings, public opinion polls, public hearings, focus groups, referenda, or meetings with stakeholders); and public participation (e.g. citizens juries, citizens’ panels, consensus conferences, scenario workshops, deliberative polls, or citizens’ dialogues).

 

Key conditions for successful public involvement

There is a consensus in the literature about the paucity of good quality evidence from research assessing public involvement process and outcome. Among the most often cited key conditions of successful public consultation and public participation are the following: representativeness; independence; early involvement; influencing policy decisions; providing information; resource accessibility; and structured decision-making.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Principles for accountability
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,HEALTH SCRUTINY]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ The NHS Confederation, through its PCT Network, embarked on a work programme to explore what local accountability is and what it is needed for. As well as wide-ranging discussions with Confederation members at regional and other meetings, the Confederation undertook an online consultation and held an expert seminar of leading academics, government advisers and a range of PCT and NHS provider executives, non-executives and chairs. This report presents their findings and is intended to open up debate. It is hoped it will also help PCTs develop their arrangements with councils, partners, local citizens, patients and communities.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Principles of community engagement
document.publisher: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,INTRODUCTION TO PPI,PPI IN PRACTICE,PRINCIPLES,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body: Published in 1997, by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Public Health Practice Program Office in Atlanta, GA., Principles of Community Engagement provides public health professionals and community leaders with a science base and practical guidelines for engaging the public in community decision-making and action for health promotion, health protection, and disease prevention. The material provided here can help public health professionals and community leaders improve communication, promote common understanding, and strengthen coordination, collaboration, and partnership efforts among themselves and community members and institutions. This book is also designed to help CDC programs and their partners guide community involvement in activities that affect or change health-related behaviours, including needs and asset assessment, planning, resource allocation, advocacy, outreach, program development, implementation, and evaluation.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Priority setting and patient and public involvement in priority setting in clinical research: a web review of UKCRN Topic Specific Research Networks
document.publisher: James Lind Alliance: Tackling treatment uncertainties together
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
The James Lind Alliance (JLA) is developing, piloting, and describing methods for shared priority setting in research that addresses treatment uncertainties. The JLA considers the United Kingdom Clinical Research Network (UKCRN) to be a key partner in raising awareness regarding the lack of shared research priorities. Members of the UKCRN have been involved in the strategic direction of the JLA since its inception.

The JLA was interested in how the UKCRN Topic Specific Research Networks developed their research ideas and set their priorities for their respective clinical research programmes, and whether/how patients and the public are involved in this work. A web review was undertaken of the Topic Specific Research Networks in parallel with a larger scoping project, with a view to comparing and contrasting the findings.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Priority setting in health care : lessons from the experiences of eight countries
document.publisher: International Journal for Equity in Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,PRIORITY SETTING]]>
document.body:
All health care systems face problems of justice and efficiency related to setting priorities for allocating a limited pool of resources to a population. Because many of the central issues are the same in all systems, the United States and other countries can learn from the successes and failures of countries that have explicitly addressed the question of health care priorities.

This article reviews explicit priority setting efforts in Norway, Sweden, Israel, the Netherlands, Denmark, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the state of Oregon in the US. The approaches used can be divided into those centred on outlining principles versus those that define practices. In order to establish the main lessons from their experiences we consider (1) the process each country used, (2) criteria to judge the success of these efforts, (3) which approaches seem to have met these criteria, and (4) using their successes and failures as a guide, how to proceed in setting priorities. We demonstrate that there is little evidence that establishment of a values framework for priority setting has had any effect on health policy, nor is there evidence that priority setting exercises have led to the envisaged ideal of an open and participatory public involvement in decision making.

This article was published in Int J Equity Health. 2008; 7: 4.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Process evaluation of the EPP : Report II : examination of the implementation of the Expert Patients Programme within the structures and locality contexts of the NHS in England (PREPP study) : how the Expert Patients Programme has been delivered and accepted in the NHS during the pilot phase
document.publisher: National Primary and Care Trust Development Programme
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,SELF MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
The Expert Patients Programme (EPP) is a NHS-based training programme that provides opportunities to people who live with long-term conditions to develop new skills to manage their condition better on a day-to-day basis. The six-week course is the mainstay of the NHS self-care support programme. The EPP is available to anyone with a long-term condition and is delivered by Primary Care Trusts (PCTs) by people who have personal experience of living with a long-term condition. The course is quality controlled through regular monitoring of the paid trainers and volunteer tutors. This summary of the research, published in June 2005, carried out by the National Primary Care Research and Development Centre (NPCRDC) examines the way EPP training was delivered, accepted and integrated into the NHS during the pilot phase when PCTs were funded to run four courses. The research took place between April 2003 and April 2005.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Process, progress and making it work : health overview and scrutiny in England 2005
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,HEALTH SCRUTINY,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
A report with findings from the first year of a three year research project being conducted by Manchester University as part of the Health Scrutiny Support Programme. The report draws on the findings of surveys of health OSCs and NHS bodies and describes an analytical framework that the research team has developed for detailed fieldwork with 10 anonymous case study sites.

The report concludes that health scrutiny is working, despite challenges around resources, joint working and consultations about 'substantial' service changes.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Promoting children and young people's participation through the National Healthy School Standard
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,CHILDREN,YOUNG PEOPLE]]>
document.body:
This briefing, informed by the views of children and young people themselves, has been developed to support the publication of the Department for Education and Science guidance ‘Working together: giving children and young people a say’ (2004). It forms part of the National Healthy School Standard strategy to support schools and local healthy schools programmes in establishing practice that will ensure the active involvement of children and young people through the provision of real opportunities to shape and influence all decisions that affect them.

 

The DfES guidance makes a clear commitment to increasing the participation of children and young people. Raising levels of successful participation in schools and their communities has been identified as a priority action area for the National Healthy School Standard. Findings from the national evaluation of the National Healthy School Standard provided evidence for the need to build on current good practice to improve the involvement of young people so as to enhance their role as decision makers at national, regional, local and school levels.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Promoting effective citizenship and community empowerment : a guide for local authorities on enhancing capacity for public participation
document.publisher: Office of the Deputy Prime Minister
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Effective local governance now requires informed, engaged citizens who vote in elections, participate in decision making and contribute to the quality of services. This means public bodies need to go beyond providing opportunities for participation, to embark on a process of learning, both for the public and for the organisations that need their input.

This guide is for councils and other bodies wishing help people develop the knowledge, skills and sense of empowerment needed to play a meaningful role in local decision-making. It's packed with advice, examples of good practice and links to useful sources of information and is structured along the lines of six key challenges:

1.    Effective citizenship - why helping people to become more effective citizens is a key issue for local authorities, and how this supports current Government policy.

2.    Learning and citizenship - formal and informal approaches to learning about participation and local governance, and reinforcing these by making public participation more meaningful.

3.    Tailoring to the target audience - reflecting the needs of different social groups, especially young, marginalised and under-represented people, and ‘the silent majority’.

4.    Changing Council Culture - how councils can adjust their internal culture, structure and ways of working to foster more effective citizenship.

5.    Measuring Success - evaluating whether people have become more informed or empowered as a result of initiatives, and whether the council has become more sensitive to their input.

6.    Sustainability - recognising that it takes time to build the confidence and ability needed for people to become effective citizens.

The guide was produced for ODPM by Cardiff University and is based on research carried out among English local authorities.

 

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Promoting informed choice : transforming health care to dispense knowledge for decision making
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,SHARED DECISION MAKING,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Ours is an era in which patients seek greater engagement in health care choices, increasing the demand for high-quality information about clinical options. Providing support for informed choice is not straightforward, however, because of challenges faced by clinicians, health systems, and consumers. Greater use of written or electronic tools can help to clarify choices for patients, but decision aids cannot replace the human element in facilitating informed choice. The ideal solution is to couple information with high-quality decision counseling to help patients understand the potential risks, benefits, and uncertainties of clinical options and to assist them in selecting the option that best accommodates their personal preferences. Decision counseling can be offered by three types of providers: clinicians who lack formal informed-choice training (“usual care”), clinicians with formal informed-choice training, or trained third parties who function as impartial decision counselors. Controlled studies are needed to determine which model is best, but none appears to be ideal. The health care system cannot truly support informed decision making without correcting the underlying obstacles that impede patient access to needed information. New information technology solutions, training programs, and reimbursement schemes are necessary. Patient demand for guidance will only increase as clinical options multiply and the world of information continues its rapid growth. Today’s health care system is unprepared for the convergence of these two burgeoning domains, and the need to address systemic deficiencies will grow more urgent over time.

 

This article was published in Ann Intern Med. 2005;143:293-300.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Promoting LGBT health and wellbeing through inclusive policy development
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?]]>
document.body:
In this paper the authors argue the importance of including gender and sexually diverse populations in policy development towards a more inclusive form of health promotion. They emphasize the need to address the broad health and wellbeing issues and needs of LGBT people, rather than exclusively using an illness-based focus such as HIV/AIDS. They critically examine the limitations of population health, the social determinants of health (SDOH), and public health goals, in light of the lack of recognition of gender and sexually diverse individuals and communities. By first acknowledging the unique health and social care needs of LGBT people, then employing anti-oppressive, critical and intersectional analyses they offer recommendations for how to make population health perspectives, public health goals, and the design of public health promotion policy more inclusive of gender and sexual diversity. In health promotion research and practice, representation matters. It matters which populations are being targeted for health promotion interventions and for what purposes, and it matters which populations are being overlooked. In Canada, current health promotion policy is informed by population health and social determinants of health (SDOH) perspectives, as demonstrated by Public Health Goals for Canada. With Canada's multicultural makeup comes the challenge of ensuring that diverse populations are equitably and effectively recognized in public health and health promotion policy.

This article can be cited as Int J Equity Health. 2009; 8: 18.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Promoting patient engagement with self-management support information: a qualitative meta-synthesis of processes inffluencing uptake
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,SELF MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Background
Patient information has been viewed as a key component of self-management. However, little attention has been given to methods of dissemination or implementation of effective information strategies. Previous problems identified with the use and implementation of patient information point to the need to explore the way in which patients engage with and use information to support self-management for chronic conditions.

Methods
Four published qualitative studies from a programme of research about self-management were analysed as a group; these included studies of the management of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); self-help in anxiety and depression (SHADE); menorrhagia, treatment, information, and preference (MENTIP) study; and self-help for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). For the analysis, we used an adapted meta-ethnographic approach to the synthesis of qualitative data in order to develop an evidence base.

Results
The ontological status and experience of the condition in everyday life was the most dominant theme to emerge from this synthesis. This, coupled with access to and experience of traditional health services responses, shaped the engagement with and use of information to support self-management. Five key elements were found which were likely to influence this: the perception and awareness of alternative self-management possibilities; the prior extent and nature of engagement with information; the extent of and ability to self-manage; opportunities for use of the information and the stage of the illness career; and congruence and synergy with the professional role.

Conclusion
People with chronic conditions need support from providers in both supply and engagement with information, in a way which gives legitimacy to the person's own self-management strategies and possible alternatives. Thus, a link could usefully be made between information offered, as well as patients' past experiences of self-management and engagement with services for their condition. The timeliness of the information should be considered, both in terms of the illness career and the type of condition (i.e., before depression gets too bad or time to reflect on existing knowledge about a condition and how it is to be managed) and in terms of the pre-existing relationship with services (i.e., options explored and tried).

More considered use of information (how it is provided, by whom, and at what point it should be introduced) is key to facilitating patients' engagement with and therefore use of information to support self-management.

This article was published in Implementation Science 2008; 3:44

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Promoting person-centred care at the front line
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE]]>
document.body:
Published in 2006, this report documents the barriers and opportunities to the delivery of person-centred support/care by frontline workers. Recent policy developments across the UK have highlighted the importance of a more ‘person-centred’ approach within community care services. Within this framework, however, little attention has been given to the role played by frontline workers in limiting, facilitating or delivering on these policy imperatives. Understanding the roles and experiences of frontline workers is crucial in understanding how frontline care can be made more ‘person-centred’. The views of service users are also key in understanding how to promote independence. This report explores frontline work within the context of service user experiences, and identifies the structural barriers within which frontline workers function. It highlights the personal attributes and qualities that frontline workers bring to their role, and the satisfactions and frustrations of their work. As well as reviewing the literature in this area, the study consulted frontline workers and service users about their experiences of providing and receiving care/support. Such consultation confirmed the findings of the literature review that, although there are examples of good and innovative frontline work, there are many structural obstacles to overcome for services to be ‘person-centred’. The report will be of interest to service providers, user organisations, service users and all those involved in developing services for older people, disabled people and people from minority ethnic communities.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Promoting the involvement of people with learning difficulties in staff recruitment : research summary
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES,CONSULTING PATIENTS AND PUBLIC,SERVICE DELIVERY,HOW DO I INVOLVE...?,PEOPLE WITH LEARNING DISABILITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.description: A summary of the report 'Committed to change?'.
document.body:
The 'Learning to Choose Staff' project aimed to promote and support the involvement of people with learning difficulties in staff recruitment. Drawing on evidence from a previous study, the project workers designed and evaluated a training and development programme for working with five different organisations providing services to people with learning difficulties in England.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public and patient empowerment conference, July 2008
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVING COMMUNITIES,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
The conference, Taking the lead - engaging people and communities, was held at the Royal Horticultural Halls, London on 8 July 2008. The conference highlighted the benefits of engaging people and communities, and the need for strategic leadership to embed organisational culture.

 

The presentations, slides and a short film are available, illustrating the content and activities on the day and offer a flavour of how the conference went to those who were unable to attend.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public and patient input : reducing the risks of healthcare-associated infection
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE,INSPECTION]]>
document.body:
For the inspection programme on health care associated infections (HCAIs) to have an impact on patients’ experience and confidence in the NHS, patients and the public need to be involved in the process, early enough to make a difference. The Healthcare Commission engaged with a number of stakeholder groups to collect information to help plan inspection visits to ensure that:

• The planning and content of its visits focus on what matters to patients and the public as well as what is important in terms of the prevention and control of HCAIs.
• Inspections are targeted, where appropriate, to respond to patient and public concerns.
• It truly understands how patients’ confidence and experience is affected, in terms of infection prevention and control.
• Better intelligence is gathered based on the experiences of those who use and know local healthcare services.
• Information is produced that is accessible and useful to patients and the public.

 This report summarises an event for stakeholders held by the Healthcare Commission to gather views on how patients and the public should be involved.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public and patient participation in healthcare : a discussion paper for the Irish health services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
The new national health strategy – Quality and Fairness - a Health System for You launched by the Government of Ireland in November 2001, set a vision for how the health system should develop over the next decade to deliver high quality care for all service users.

This strategy set out a series of actions for achieving increased patient involvement on a number of different levels in healthcare. It will be the responsibility of named agencies to set up and oversee the implementation of these actions.

This is a research based discussion paper on public and patient participation in healthcare commissioned from the Health Services Research Centre by the Office for Health Management In response to the proposals for a people-centred care outlined in the strategy.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public and patient participation in primary care groups: new beginnings for old power structures
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body: The report examines two models of engagement which emerged from qualitative research into public and patient involvement in Primary Care Groups. The models described reflect the boards’ emphasis upon their role, either in the improvement in health within the locality or, more narrowly defined, as improvement in the efficiency of health services. The significance of the conceptualisation of patients and public as consumers or as citizens is considered and the consequences of these conceptualisations for levels of empowerment are developed. The authors conclude that in adopting the health improvement model, primary care organisations can seize an opportunity to involve their local communities in empowering processes which have benefits for the development of the health and social capital of those communities. The importance of such engagement forming the centre of a network of responsive local services is identified.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public attitudes to self care : baseline survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,SELF MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body: To feed into the policy context of self care support in the DH and NHS, the Department of Health commissioned MORI to conduct a survey of the English public to establish a baseline of public attitudes towards self care and their self care behaviours. The baseline data has been collected to help assess the impact of recent initiatives on the public a few years down the line - and to inform care policy in the short and medium term future. The survey was conducted in two stages between August 2004 and January 2005. The ‘Public Attitudes to Self Care - Baseline Survey’ sets out the findings of this survey.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public consultation toolkit
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,CONSULTING PATIENTS AND PUBLIC,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
The toolkit was designed for staff working for the London Borough of Waltham Forest to help them plan, carry out and evaluate consultations. The appendices provide additional resources and support.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public deliberation : a manager's guide to citizen engagement
document.publisher: IBM Center for the Business of Government
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES]]>
document.body:
The purpose of this guide to citizen engagement, published in the United States in 2006, was to strengthen the foundation for participatory governance within the federal government, in particular in agency decision making. The guide provides examples of experimentation with new techniques to engage citizens at all levels of governance, thereby encouraging federal managers to see themselves as potential agents within this movement to reinvigorate democratic governance.

This guide is composed of four main sections: The first conducts a quick inventory of existing policy frameworks for citizen participation and summarizes the shortcomings of current practice as it is shaped by these policy guidelines. The guide will then introduce an emerging field of practice known as “deliberative democracy” and provide some examples of where citizens engage face-to-face in addressing community issues. The third section moves into the online world, which has sparked innovation and experimentation and has yielded several interesting techniques of which agency managers should be aware. Fourth, a concise summary is supplied of key features and techniques for deliberation within a framework for understanding how they can complement policy and program development. In the same section there is an inventory of some of the most promising techniques as a starting point for agency managers to “pick and choose” among methods. The guide concludes with a set of recommendations.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public deliberation at the local level : participatory budgeting in Brazil
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This paper was presented at the Experiments for Deliberative Democracy Conference, held in Wisconsin in January 2000. It looks at the emergence of participatory budgeting process in Brazil.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public engagement - Connecting for Health
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ Information is provided about different methods of public engagement undertaken by Connecting for Health; consultations, partnerships, patient and public representatives and the Voluntary Sector National Advisory Group.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public engagement (Part 1): Engaging the public in healthcare policy - why do it? and what are the challenges?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,INTRODUCTION TO PPI,PRINCIPLES]]>
document.body:
Published in February 2009, the key findings of this pamphlet are

The opinions and perspectives of the public play a valuable role in developing high-quality, evidence-informed policy guidance.

Engaging the public in health policy decisions can increase the public’s trust and confidence in their healthcare system.

The public holds important health knowledge, but this knowledge should be applied carefully and appropriately, in line with the context and purpose of the decision in question.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public engagement (Part II): how do deliberative processes achieve meaningful public engagement?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,INTRODUCTION TO PPI,PRINCIPLES]]>
document.body:
Published in February 2009, the key findings of this pamphlet are:

Deliberative processes are often relied upon to capture the diverse perspectives of members of the general public, patients, and others on a wide range of healthcare topics

Using deliberative processes encourages informed public dialogue and leads to policy recommendations that incorporate various points of view.

Deliberative processes that focus on concrete recommendations are more likely to have a direct influence on healthcare decision-making.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public engagement (Part III): how is it done? how can we tell if it's effective?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
Published in June 2009, the key findings of this pamphlet are:

Choosing the most effective strategy for engaging the public should be based primarily on the intended goal of the dialogue. However, other contextual factors, such as types of issues, resources or community characteristics, also shape how the public should be engaged.

A public engagement strategy should identify who will be engaged; the level of engagement; and the decision-making phase during which the public is involved.

Frameworks and criteria for evaluating public engagement strategies can help in assessing effectiveness, but no evaluation tool trumps the importance of having a clearly defined goal and strategy.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public engagement in setting priorities in health care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,PRIORITY SETTING]]>
document.body:
The key points of this article are:

 

• The public is the most important stakeholder in the healthcare system.

• Engagement of the public in priority setting in health care is in keeping with the ideals of a democracy.

• Members of the public can provide a crucial perspective about the values and priorities of the community, which should lead to higher-quality decisions in priority setting.

• Engagement of the public should improve the public’s trust and confidence in the health care system.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public engagement on global health challenges
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,INTRODUCTION TO PPI,PRINCIPLES]]>
document.body:
Background: Experience with public engagement activities regarding the risks and benefits of science and technology (S&T) is growing, especially in the industrialized world. However, public engagement in the developing world regarding S&T risks and benefits to explore health issues has not been widely explored.

 

Methods: This paper gives an overview about public engagement and related concepts, with a particular focus on challenges and benefits in the developing world. We then describe an Internet-based platform, which seeks to both inform and engage youth and the broader public on global water issues and their health impacts. Finally, we outline a possible course for future action to scale up this and similar online public engagement platforms.

 

Results: The benefits of public engagement include creating an informed citizenry, generating new ideas from the public, increasing the chances of research being adopted, increasing public trust, and answering ethical research questions. Public engagement also fosters global communication, enables shared experiences and methodology, standardizes strategy, and generates global viewpoints. This is especially pertinent to the developing world, as it encourages previously marginalized populations to participate on a global stage. One of the core issues at stake in public engagement is global governance of science and technology. Also, beyond benefiting society at large, public engagement in science offers benefits to the scientific enterprise itself.

 

Conclusion: Successful public engagement with developing world stakeholders will be a critical part of implementing new services and technologies. Interactive engagement platforms, such as the Internet, have the potential to unite people globally around relevant health issues.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public Information Pack
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH]]>
document.description: A set of four booklets for members of the public who are interested in getting involved in NHS, public health and social care research.
document.body:
This pack, published in March 2007 is for members of the public who are interested in getting involved in NHS, public health or social care research. Made up of four booklets, the pack has been produced by INVOLVE with support and advice from the public.

The four booklets are:

So what is it all about? - gives some background information about research and public involvement, and why it is important for the public to be involved in research.

Getting started - describes some of the ways the public can be get involved in research and suggests questions to ask before deciding whether to get involved, as well as giving ideas about how to get started.

Finding out more - provides information about some of the different organisations that are involved in research which may be useful to know about. It also lists details of the articles, books and reports referred to in the other booklets.

Jargon buster - provides a glossary of some of the words used in the other booklets. These definitions have been developed in consultation with a panel of researchers and a panel of service users.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public input on the future of health care : results from the consultation workbook
document.publisher: Commission on the Future of Health Care in Canada
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES,FORUMS FOR DEBATE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Faced with the challenge of facilitating informed public input from as many Canadians as possible, the Commission on the Future of Health Care produced a consultation workbook. The workbook included facts and arguments about the future of health care, four scenarios for the future and a set of questions. Canadians could either access and complete the workbook on-line or complete it on paper and forward their answers to the Commission. A total of 16,463 on-line workbooks and 1,083 paper-based workbooks were completed. Published in November 2002, this report gives a profile of the respondents and summarises their preferences.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public involvement among first wave applicants for Foundation Trust status
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
This short report, published in November 2003, looks at examples of good practice in creating a broad membership base in foundation trusts and in making the case to local people for foundation status.

 

It aimed to determine:

 

            • What had been said to local people would be the benefits of foundation status;

            • How the potential disadvantages of foundation status would be tackled;

            • How local support for their application has been sought;

            • How it was proposed to build the public membership constituency, should the application be successful;

            • How trusts have worked with PCTs, community and voluntary groups, local authorities, MPs and other local ‘influencers’;

            • To what extent, and how, they have reached out to excluded groups;

            • Whether there is any evidence their efforts have been successful to date.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public involvement groups
document.publisher: Cancer Care Research Centre, University of Stirling
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,CONSULTING PATIENTS AND PUBLIC,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Many people have worries and concerns about cancer and cancer treatment which can sometimes affect how they view cancer. By listening to the public across Scotland the Cancer Care Research Centre at the University of Stirling hoped to understand what a variety of Scottish people think about cancer and cancer care. They worked with local areas in a number of ways to gather a range of information. This included using cancer statistics for the area, interviewing key health and social care workers, holding open meetings and small discussion groups.

To ensure that they heard what a variety of people had to say they made sure that they spoke to people from urban, rural and semi-rural populations, including the islands; those from poorer as well as wealthy areas; and people who do not always have the chance to get their views heard in healthcare like minority ethnic groups, children and men. They will be using the results to develop research at the Centre to improve cancer care.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public involvement in health care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,INTRODUCTION TO PPI,PPI IN PRACTICE,POLICY]]>
document.body:
The government is promoting public involvement in health care as part of new NHS policy.  Proposals include allowing the public to elect members of the governing boards of foundation trusts and primary care trusts' obligations to engage with the public.  The authors consider, however, that clarity and consensus are lacking about what public involvement means in health care, why it is desirable, and whether current policies will meet the desired objectives. They examine the latest polices and their potential effects.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public involvement in medical research
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH]]>
document.body: There is information on consultations (finding out what MRC stakeholders think about key issues in medical research), public involvement in medical research (examples of how the public is involved in MRC funded medical research) and the MRC public panel (a system for matching suitable lay people to specific MRC activities in which a patient or public perspective would add value).]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public involvement in the priority-setting activities of a wait time management initiative : a qualitative case study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,PRIORITY SETTING]]>
document.body:
Background
As no health system can afford to provide all possible services and treatments for the people it serves, each system must set priorities. Priority setting decision makers are increasingly involving the public in policy making. This study focuses on public engagement in a key priority setting context that plagues every health system around the world: wait list management. The purpose of this study is to describe and evaluate priority setting for the Ontario Wait Time Strategy, with special attention to public engagement.

Methods

This study was conducted at the Ontario Wait Time Strategy in Ontario, Canada which is part of a Federal-Territorial-Provincial initiative to improve access and reduce wait times in five areas: cancer, cardiac, sight restoration, joint replacements, and diagnostic imaging. There were two sources of data: (1) over 25 documents (e.g. strategic planning reports, public updates), and (2) 28 one-on-one interviews with informants (e.g. OWTS participants, MOHLTC representatives, clinicians, patient advocates). Analysis used a modified thematic technique in three phases: open coding, axial coding, and evaluation.

 

Results

The Ontario Wait Time Strategy partially meets the four conditions of 'accountability for reasonableness'. The public was not directly involved in the priority setting activities of the Ontario Wait Time Strategy. Study participants identified both benefits (supporting the initiative, experts of the lived experience, a publicly funded system and sustainability of the healthcare system) and concerns (personal biases, lack of interest to be involved, time constraints, and level of technicality) for public involvement in the Ontario Wait Time Strategy. Additionally, the participants identified concern for the consequences (sustainability, cannibalism, and a class system) resulting from the Ontario Wait Times Strategy.

 

Conclusion

The authors described and evaluated a wait time management initiative (the Ontario Wait Time Strategy) with special attention to public engagement, and provided a concrete plan to operationalize a strategy for improving public involvement in this, and other, wait time initiatives.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public officials and community involvement in local services
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,PPI IN PRACTICE]]>
document.body:
This report is an examination of community involvement in the governance of local services, with an emphasis on the role of public officials.

The role played by public officials in community engagement has important effects on the extent to which community views can influence local services. This study explores the experiences and views of public officials, comparing a local authority, a police service and a Primary Care Trust in one part of London.

The research examines:

public officials'' perspectives on the purposes of community engagement, the different types of engagement mechanisms used, and the role played by community participants,

organisational constraints and enablers of community engagement, including senior management support, resources, performance management systems, time frames and organisational culture,

the informal practices and processes used by public officials to engage with the community and their attitudes and feelings towards it, and

the extent of community influence and the factors which affected this.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public opinion on systems for feeding back views to the National Health Service
document.publisher: Quality and Safety in Health Care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT]]>
document.body:
Objectives: To explore public opinions about different systems for feeding back views about health services to the National Health Service.

Design: Questionnaire survey.

Setting: NHS Grampian, Scotland, UK.

Participants: A random sample of 10 000 adults registered with a general practitioner in Grampian was invited to opt in to the study; 2449 were sent questionnaires.

Outcome measures: Opinions about different feedback mechanisms and their likely effectiveness in three scenarios; reasons for preferring particular mechanisms.

Results: Of 1951 respondents, over 80% thought patient representatives would be a good way for people to pass on their ideas about the NHS and would help to improve it. Patient representatives were the most widely preferred course of action for two out of three scenarios. People explained their preferences for particular feedback systems mainly in terms of their ease of use, the perception that they would be listened to, and the likelihood of anything being done about what they said. However, people varied in their judgements about the likely effectiveness of different feedback systems. Preferences for particular systems varied according to the types of situation considered. Some people are reluctant to approach clinical staff with concerns about healthcare quality. A substantial minority have no confidence that their concerns would be listened to or acted upon, however they were expressed.

Conclusion: The "patient representative" function has substantial popular support and could facilitate local learning and action to improve the quality of health services from users’ perspectives. Feedback systems must demonstrate their effectiveness if they are to gain and retain public confidence.

The article was published in Qual Saf Health Care 2003;12:435-442

Access to articles from Quality and Safety in Health Care requires registration, which is free of charge.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public participation and citizen governance in the Canadian health system
document.publisher: Commission on the Future of Health Care in Canada
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,INTRODUCTION TO PPI,PPI IN PRACTICE,PRINCIPLES,POLICY]]>
document.body:
This is Discussion Paper 7 in a series produced in connection with the Commission on the Future of Health Care in Canada, published in 2002.  The report looks at how public participation can contribute to the health system and the expression of democratic values, the Canadian experience with public participation in the governance of the health system, and the future of public participation and citizen governance in the health system.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public participation in local government : a survey of local authorities
document.publisher: Office of the Deputy Prime Minister
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES]]>
document.body:
Local authorities have long had statutory responsibilities to consult and involve the public in relation to certain issues, such as land-use planning, through public meetings and consultation documents. Research commissioned by the Department in 1997 revealed that not only have local authorities been using such traditional methods, so called ‘consumerist’ approaches (service satisfactions surveys, complaints/suggestions schemes) have also become well-established in local government. Also, there were signs of local government looking to new and innovative ways of involving the public. This research is intended to gauge further developments in local government use of public participation approaches, particularly in the light of early implementation of modernisation policies and initiatives. This report was published in December 2002.

]]>

document.title: Public value and participation: a literature review for the Scottish government
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,ACCOUNTABILITY,SERVICE PROVISION AND PLANNING,PPI IN PRACTICE,COLLECTIVE INVOLVEMENT,MONITORING AND QUALITY ASSURANCE,PRIORITY SETTING]]>
document.body: <![CDATA[ This paper provides a brief account of the theory of public value and outlines how public participation can contribute to the process of authorising what public managers do, establishing priorities and decision making and measuring the performance of public organisations.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public views on choices in health and health care : a qualitative study
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE]]>
document.body: Extending patient choice is central to the government’s reform of the NHS. Patients will be offered a choice of hospitals for planned operations from December 2005 and will soon be offered choice in other areas of health care. This paper presents the key findings from ten focus groups held to explore public views about choice in health and health care and aims particularly to describe attitudes to choice among people living with a long-term condition. It concludes with a discussion about the implications of findings for emerging policy. The findings will inform the design of a larger quantitative survey about choice, to be conducted towards the end of 2005.]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Public views on healthcare performance indicators and patient choice
document.publisher: Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,PATIENT CHOICE]]>
document.body:
Patients on certain waiting lists in the UK National Health Service (NHS) are now offered the choice of persevering with their home hospital or switching to another hospital where they will be treated on a guaranteed date. Such decisions require knowledge of performance. We used facilitated focus groups to investigate the views of patients and members of the public on publication of information about the performance of healthcare providers. Six groups with a total of 50 participants met in six different locations in England.

Participants felt that independent monitoring of healthcare performance is necessary, but they were ambivalent about the value of performance indicators and hospital rankings. They tended to distrust government information and preferred the presentational style of 'Dr Foster', a commercial information provider, because it gave more detailed locally relevant information. Many participants felt the NHS did not offer much scope for choice of provider.

If public access to performance information is to succeed in informing referral decisions and raising quality standards, the public and general practitioners will need education on how to interpret and use the data.

This article was published in J R Soc Med 2003;96:338-342.

  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Patient and Public Involvement]]>
document.title: Publication guidance for comment cards
document.topics: <![CDATA[ PATIENT AND PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT,PPI IN PRACTICE,TECHNIQUES,INVOLVEMENT MECHANISM,PATIENT EXPERIENCE,INDIVIDUAL INVOLVEMENT,GETTING INFORMATION]]>
document.body:
The NHS Plan, Chapter 10, stated that:

"All NHS trusts, primary care groups and primary care trusts have to ask patients and carers for their views on the services they recieved"

"All patients leaving hospital will be given the opportunity to record their views about the standards of care they have recieved, in writing or electronically through new bedside TV information services"

This guidance will help in the  production of a local comment card using a standard national template.
